summary.seg: Trinity College MS O.9.10 is a medical and religious compilation of the fifteenth century, produced in England, and apparently owned by one John Gylberd in the fifteenth century and William Feelde (or Feld) in the sixteenth century. Feelde seems to have been a self-conscious and eager Elizabethan courtier, as he added his signature throughout the manuscript, various pen trials and snatches of poetry, along with several drawings of Elizabeth, a palace (perhaps Hampton Court), cannons and warfare, and a well-dressed man (perhaps himself). Most of the texts are written neatly in the same fifteenth-century hand in two columns with red initials, the key exception being a combined herbal and lapidary (ff. 89-113) of the fourteenth century with alternating initials in red and blue. It appears that the fifteenth-century scribe built a new collection, dedicated to physical and spiritual healing, around the core of the older herbal. Another addition (on the flyleaves, ff. iii-iv) by a different fifteenth-century scribe is a Latin poem titled Remedy against the Pestilence, based on the hugely popular plague treatise of John of Burgundy. All the texts in the manuscript are in Latin except for a Sphere of Apuleius diagram with French text (f. 75v) and two recipes in English (f. 142r), for a migraine and for webbe in oculo ('web in the eye', i.e. a cataract). English glosses are added to some recipes and titles in the herbal.

The owners of this manuscript could find within it all the tools they needed to diagnose, prognosticate, and treat maladies of the body, mind, or soul, along with reference texts for helping them understand the difficult terminology of learned medicine. Trinity College MS O.9.10 contains over twenty different items, primarily medical, in 144 folios. The core texts are an antidotary called Liber Galieni ('The Book of Galen') (ff. 27-49), a tabular glossary of medical terms from the Canon of Avicenna (ff. 52-66), another medical dictionary (ff. 121-136), and a composite verse herbal made of poems by Macer Floridus, Henry of Huntingdon, Marbod of Rennes, and versified passages from other medical texts (ff. 89-108r). This manuscript belongs to a distinctly English tradition of large medical collections built around a central verse herbal compilation, containing mostly poems from Macer's De viribus herbarum ('On the Virtues of Herbs') supplemented with poems from its English imitator, Henry of Huntingdon's Anglicanus ortus ('The English Garden'). The Royal manuscript collection in the British Library includes three other medical collections that follow the same pattern as this medical miscellany: Royal MS 12 B.xii, Royal MS 12 B.xxiiii, and Royal MS 12 B.xxiv. Trinity College MS O.9.10 is distinguished from these other collections by the inclusion of two devotional texts, written in the same hand as the surrounding medical treatises: a Passio Christi (the so-called Gospel of Nicodemus, ff. 76-84) and a set of salutations to the Virgin Mary (ff. 87-89), curiously interrupted by a short treatise on uroscopy (ff. 84-87). The mixture of medical and religious texts shows that readers and scribes in this period viewed health holistically, thinking about the welfare of both body and soul and grouping together physical and spiritual remedies.

Dr Winston Black
Gatto Chair of Christian Studies
St Francis Xavier University
Antigonish, Nova Scotia, Canada

msItem.title: Added line
msItem.incipit: i verso ?fuerint duo viri religiosissum qui abstinentes coitus
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 15th century.

msItem.title: Saying
msItem.incipit: ii verso Anger is thrall
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Draft sentence
msItem.incipit: ii verso The secound day
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added (upside down) in red ink the 16th century.

msItem.title: Medical treatment for the plague in verse
msItem.incipit: iii recto De cura preseruatia De replecione et coitu: Homo si vis te preseruare / Summe debes enitare - Replecionem nimiam
msItem.explicit: iv recto Vt dictum est age curando / Dei opem implorando - Et viues deo dante. Amen
msItem.finalRubric: iv recto ffinitur receptus cathedralis ingressus cuisudam Baccalarij in medicinis vniuersitatis Cantabrigie contra epidemiam Amen - Whalsgraue

msItem.title: Medical recipe for treating the plague
msItem.note: Added in the 15th century.

msItem.title: Alphabetical glossary of medical terms, including diseases and plant names
msItem.textLang: Latin with Middle English names and glosses
msItem.incipit: 1r Aaronid est cokkispintil iarus pes uituliid est folefot
msItem.explicit: 26v Zucoraria .n. in metridato flos Agni casti
msItem.note: Shows similarities with the glossary called Synonyma Bartholomei.

msItem.title: List of weights and measures and their apothecary symbols
msItem.incipit: 26v A grane - gr
msItem.explicit: 26v In nomber - n2
msItem.note: Added in the (?) 16th century.

msItem.title: Antidotarium magnum (abbreviated version), here referred to as Liber Galiani
msItem.rubric: 27r Incipit liber Antidotarij Nicholi mesue Rasis et Galieni
msItem.incipit: 27r Antidotarium . Aurea Alexandrina ffaciens ad reuma capitis
msItem.explicit: 49v Si non pillulas informes dabis .xv. vel .xvj. addito sufficienti di[agri]dio

msItem.title: Draft indenture
msItem.incipit: 38v Nouerint vniuersi per praesentes me Johannem ffeld de Culneham in Comitatu Oxonie gent. teneri et firmiter
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added (upside down) by William Field in the 16th century. John de Culneham [Culham, Oxfordshire] is also referred to on f. 70: John (upside down) and John de Cul[?ham] (upside down). His first name Johannem may also be referred to in the outer margin of f. 56r.

msItem.title: Examples of three scripts and their names
msItem.incipit: 27r (outer margin) Court hand / Secretary / Romaine
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century.
The names of the three scripts are written in their respective scripts (Anglicana, Secretary and Italic). A simimlar note, written by the same hand, can be found on f. 33r (outer margin).

msItem.title: Examples of three scripts and their names
msItem.incipit: 33r (outer margin) Court hand it is / Secretory hande / Romaine hand
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century.
The names of the three scripts are written in their respective scripts (Anglicana, Secretary and Italic). A simimlar note, written by the same hand, can be found on f. 33r (outer margin).

msItem.title: Date reference (? 1 June/July 1560/1)
msItem.incipit: 44v (lower margin) The first day of the moneth of J[un] [corrected to July below?] of the thrid year of our soueraigne lady
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added (upside down) in red ink in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Title for a motet for the feast of St John the Baptist
msItem.incipit: 44v (upper margin) Inter natos mulierum [...]
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Draft sentence
msItem.incipit: 46r (upper margin) That I may shew meye vnto thowsand
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Verse couplet
msItem.incipit: 49v (lower margin) In my beginninge god be my speede / in grace and vertue to proceede
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added (updside down) in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Verse couplet
msItem.incipit: 49v (lower margin) In my beginninge god be my speede / in grace and vertue to proceede
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added (updside down) in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Draft letter
msItem.incipit: 52v (outer margin) To his very Lovinge brother Const[able]
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Saying
msItem.incipit: 53r (outer margin) Qui bene bibit bene dormit
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century, perhaps by William Field. The same saying can also be found on f. 56r (outer margin but it was later erased and is now only legible with UV light.

msItem.title: On the use of herbs in chirurgy
msItem.incipit: 50r Melago tenet plagam apertam
msItem.explicit: 50r In sero remoue et ?econuerso

msItem.title: Alphabetical glossary of medical terms
msItem.incipit: 52r Alphatius. Idem quod medicus
msItem.explicit: 66v Zegi id est Attramentum vel uitreolum
msItem.finalRubric: 66v Explicit Tabula Auicenne ffen super Interpretaciones dictionum Ebraicarum Grecarum et eciam Persidarum script. per ffratrem Johannem Holbeche .M. ordinis minorum

msItem.title: Draft indenture
msItem.incipit: 55r (outer margin) This Indenture made the xxvth daye of monthe.
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century by William Field.

msItem.title: Reference to the office of cook in the household of Elizabeth I
msItem.incipit: 55r (lower margin) But in offic. Coquine domine Regine Elizabethe
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century. The same reference can be found on f. 55r (lower margin).

msItem.title: Draft indenture
msItem.incipit: 60v (outer margin) Noverint vniuersi per praesentes
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century by William Field.

msItem.title: Prognostications for the months of the year
msItem.rubric: 67r Incipiunt Pronosticaciones et ffortuna cuiuscumque persone secundum signa Zodiaci
msItem.incipit: 67r Marcius - Qui natus ffuerit sub signo Arietis qui Incipit A .xvijo die . marcij . vsque ad .xvij. diem Aprilis habet supercilia[m] magnam
msItem.explicit: 71v in filijs habundabit innumeris
msItem.note: The text discusses the fortunes of men and women separately.

msItem.title: Name inscription
msItem.incipit: 70v (outer margin) Thomas Helmet de Culueham
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century by William Field perhaps as a draft indenture.

msItem.title: Astrological tract on the Seven Planets
msItem.author: ? Walter Burley
msItem.incipit: 72r Sciendum quod quando aliquis nascitur in aliqua hora diei in qua dominatur aliquam septem planetarum primorum erit
msItem.explicit: 73r Quod si fecerit praemia a deo dignam recipiet in pepetuum. Ita fiat Amen
msItem.note: Gensler (2004) discusses and edits two other copies of this treatise, entitled De planetis et eorum virtute, in Lambeth, Palace Library, MSS 70 and 74. Gensler states that the Lambeth texts are the only identified medieval copies of the work (p. 209). Since both manuscripts contain works by Walter Burley, scholars have atributed it to Burley as well. However, there is no evidence for his authorship. Considering that this treatise also occurs outside the context of Burley's works, this attribution seems extremely tenuous.

msItem.title: Prayer exhortation
msItem.incipit: 72r (upper margin) Lord ffor thy namis sake graunt vs this
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Treatise on bloodletting
msItem.textLang: Middle English text with Latin title
msItem.rubric: 73r Tractatus de dimininucione Sanguinis in diuersis mensibus
msItem.incipit: 73r Here he tellith what day is good to belde on ffor diuerse maledies . In euery monthe
msItem.explicit: 75v The .ij. ueynys on þe litil toon on eythir ffoot tho seruen for þe Reynes and þe bladder and for þe palseye and þe gowte and whan þou bledist on þe feet þou most put hem in hot water
msItem.note: The treatise contains various suheadings, including De virtutibus ffleugbotomie (f. 73r); Nota de tribus fferijs secundis in anno in quibus nullus debet fflegbotimari (f. 73v); De venis in corpore (f. 73v); Dies periculisi (f. 73v); and a section on phlebotomy for veins in each location from head to foot (ff. 74r-75v)

msItem.title: Apuleian Sphere [Spera Pictagora]
msItem.incipit: 75v Ceste la esper de Epeleron de diciple Platoun de la vie et de la mort et de lez maladez
msItem.explicit: 75v samadi .xxv. vel .xxj.

msItem.title: Tract on the governance of the body by the Signs of the Zodiac
msItem.incipit: 76r Notandum quod quando luna est in Ariete tunc dominatur principue super capud et faciem
msItem.explicit: 76r Quando in piscibus tunc super pedes etcaetera
msItem.note: The tract accompanies a large full-page drawing of a Zodiac Man (crowned).

msItem.title: Note on bloodletting
msItem.incipit: 76r Item Notandum quo[d] periculum est wlnerari vel ledi in aliquo membro corporis luna existente in tali signo . qua humores tunc defluunt cicius et putrescunt . et morbi In cura biles et ad Curandum difficiles procreantur ut sepe Probatum est
msItem.note: Full transcription. The tract accompanies a large full-page drawing of a Zodiac Man (crowned).

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: 76r (outer margin) Sidera non tot habet celum nec flumina pisces / Quot scelera gerit femina mente Dolos
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Draft sentence
msItem.incipit: 76r That I may serve
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century. The same sentence is written in red ink on f. 94r (upper margin).

msItem.title: Gospel of Nichodemus
msItem.rubric: 76v Passio domini nostri ihesu Christi Secundum Nichodemum
msItem.incipit: 76v Factum est anno .xc.o Imperij tiberij Cesaris herodis filij herodis regis Galilee
msItem.explicit: 84v idem Jhesus qui iam regnat in Celis . Cui sit laus et gloria in saeculorum saecula. Amen

msItem.title: Treatise on uroscopy
msItem.incipit: 84v Omnis vrina est colamentum sanguinis
msItem.explicit: 87v Et principue si sit quasi oleagina nisi sit die cretica . tunc significat salutem si patiens ben dormiat

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: 85r (outer margin) Sicut aquam [sic: aqua] extinguit ignis [sic: ignem] sic Elemosinam extinguit peccatum
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century. The same inscription can be found on f. 90r (lower margin) but there it is accompanied by an English translation.

msItem.title: Treatise on devotion to the Virgin Mary with extracts from De Laudibus Mariae
msItem.author: Pseudo-Albertus Magnus
msItem.rubric: 87v Incipit devota meditacio ad salutacionem virginis marie
msItem.incipit: 87v Auctor de laudibus beate uirginis libo secundo dicit quod debemus laudare benedicere beatam Mariam Christi Jhesu matrem corde ore et opere
msItem.note: This tract contains an indulgenced instruction for twenty salutations (Hail Maries) to different parts of the Virgin Mary's body that need to be peformed in front of an image of her; the Hail Mary; an instruction to venerate the Five Joys of the Virgin Mary that with each Joy dedicated to one of the letters of the name Maria , featuring prayers that being with the letters in question (Ad laudem quinque Gaudiorum virginis marie per quinque litteras nomini suo adaptatas scilicet maria); and ending with a prayer to the titles of the Virgin Mary, beginning: Salue uirgo gloriosa / Parens femina formosa / ffunde preces pulcra rosa - Pro nobis ad filium.

listBibl.bibl: Borgnet and Borgnet (1898), p. 111 [Book 2, Chapter 5 (Quomodo Mariae sit serviendum de ore?)]

msItem.title: Prayer to be said while collecting herbs
msItem.rubric: 89r Oracio super herbas et olera virencia
msItem.incipit: 89r Deus qui in mundo primordiali inicio inter cetera eciam virencia crescere et multiplicari precepisti ; te subnixis et humilimis exoramus precibus . vt has herbas in vsum medicinale collectas seu colligatas . in tuo sancto nomine consecres et benedicas . vt quicumque ex eis potamina vel vnguenta gustauerint . Sanitatem cordis et corporis percipere mercantur . Per Christum dominum.
msItem.note: Full transcription. For a similar prayer, see Heffernan, Carol F. “The Wyse Boke of Maystyr Peers of Salerne: Edition and Study of a Fourteenth-Century Treatise of Popular Medicine.” Manuscripta 37, n. 3 (1993): 291-321

msItem.title: Compilation of poems on herbs
msItem.author: Floridus Macer (attributed)
msItem.incipit: 89r De Arthemesia: Herbarum quasdam dicturus carmine herbarum matrem dedit arthemesia nomen Cui grecus sermo iustum puto pouere primo
msItem.explicit: 108r Papulas eius istud cathaplasma resoluit
msItem.note: A compilation of ninety poems on herbs drawn from Macer Floridus, Henry of Huntingdon (Anglicanus ortus), Pseudo-Apuleius, Constantine the African, and other sources.

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: 90r (lower margin) Sicut aquam [sic: aqua] extinguit ignis [sic: ignem] sic Elemosinam extinguit peccatum
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added (upside down) in the 16th century. The same inscription can be found on f. 85r (outer margin).

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: 90r (lower margin) Lattine: Sicut aquam [sic: aqua] extinguit ignis [sic: ignem] sic Elemosinam extinguit peccatum - Anglice: like as the water doth quenche the fire . So dothe almose dedes quenche sinne
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added (upside down) in the 16th century. The same inscription can be found on f. 85r (outer margin) but without an English translation.

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: 93v (upper margin) Wisdom garnishethe ryches and shadoweth pouerty Amen
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century. The same proverb can be found in William Baldwin, The Sayings of the Wise, or Food for Thought. A Book of Moral Wisdom, Gathered from the Ancient Philosophers, ed. by (London: Stock, 1908), p. 127.

msItem.title: Draft sentence
msItem.incipit: 94r (upper margin) That I may serve thankes
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century. The same sentence is written in red ink on f. 76r.

msItem.title: Draft indenture
msItem.incipit: 96r (lower margin) Nouerint vniuersi per praesentes me John de ff de Witnam in Comitatu Berk gent. teneri et firmiter obligari Thomam Ce[...]
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added (upside down) by William Field in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Draft title of Queen Elizabeth I by William Field
msItem.incipit: 96r (lower margin) serenissimi et invictissimi domine Regine Elizabeth fidei defens
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added (upside down) in the 16th century. The title is preceded by the word haberdasher, also in William Field's hand.

msItem.title: Date reference (1559/60)
msItem.incipit: 98r (upper margin) Anno secundo Regine Elizabethe
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century. The same date reference can be found on f. 107r (upper margin).

msItem.title: Date reference (1559/60)
msItem.incipit: 107r (upper margin) Anno secundo Regine Elizabethe
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century. The same date reference can be found on f. 98r (upper margin)

msItem.title: Prognostic poem on the signs of death
msItem.incipit: 108r His signis moriens certis cognoscitur eger
msItem.explicit: 108r Si que senex dormit designat morte resolui

msItem.title: Table of contents for the Liber lapidum
msItem.author: Marbod of Rennes
msItem.rubric: 108r Incipit tabula libri Marboti de Lapidibus
msItem.incipit: 108r .i. De adamante
msItem.explicit: 108r .lx. De Crisssopassio
msItem.finalRubric: 108r Expliciunt Capitula libri Marboti de Lapidibus

msItem.title: Liber lapidum
msItem.author: Marbod of Rennes
msItem.incipit: 108v Evax rex arabum legitur scripsisse neroni
msItem.explicit: 113v Quicquid eis datur deus omnipotens operatur

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes
msItem.note: Two of the medical recipes are attributed to the Franciscan friar and medical practitioner William Holme (fl. 1380-1415): Per W. Holm and Expertum per .W. Holm.

msItem.title: Treatise with medical recipes for treating head, chest, and stomach ailments
msItem.author: William Holme
msItem.incipit: 114r Incipit Cura Capitis: Pillule pro dolore capitis . que purgant omnes malos humores . generant leticiam . auferunt tristiciam . mentem accuunt . visum reddunt . memoriam conseruant non permittunt ante tempus canestere
msItem.explicit: 119r sume mane et sero
msItem.finalRubric: 119r Explicit Tractatus de Medicinis ffratris Wilelmi Holm de Ordine Minorum

msItem.title: List of medical simples
msItem.incipit: 119v Aro astrologia .ro[tunda]. ruta domestica dupliciter / Pro acacia succus lentisci vel Incaustum quod fit de
msItem.explicit: 120v Pro Aloe absinthium
msItem.note: Another 15th-century hand has added one line below the original text: Pro osse de corde cerui . rasure cornu eiusdem
A very similiar text is edited from a manuscript in Paris in Julius Leopold Pagel, Die angebliche Chirurgie des Johannes Mesuë, jun. (Berlin: August Hirschwald, 1893), pp. 69-72.

msItem.title: Draft sentences
msItem.incipit: 125r (outer margin) That I may render vnto the / That I may render vnto the / The things that I haue deserued
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added (upside down) in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Medical dictionary
msItem.incipit: 121r Ametistus ut dicit Ys. Eth. xvj.o inter purpureas gemmas principatum tenet in India inuenitur
msItem.explicit: 136v Constrigit eciam lacrimas ex humore frigido quia propter caliditatem suam contemperat omnem frigiditatem. Praestante deo viuo qui omnia creauit et viuit in saecula saeculorum Amen
msItem.finalRubric: 136v Explicit libro sit laus / Et Gloria Cristo

msItem.title: Reference to the office of cook in the household of Elizabeth I
msItem.incipit: 125r (outer margin) But in offic. Coquine domine Regine Elizabeth
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added in the 16th century. The same reference can be found on f. 55r (lower margin).

msItem.title: Circa instans (Alphabetical list of medicines, from aloes to zuccarum)
msItem.author: Matthaeus Platearius (attributed)
msItem.incipit: 137r Aloen . Calidum et sicum in .2.o gradu
msItem.explicit: 140v Zucarium [...] uirtutem habet humectandi infrigidandi nutriendi laxandi

msItem.title: Collection of medical recipes and notes
msItem.note: The collection is in Latin except for the last two recipes, which are in Middle English: Pro Emigraneo and Pro \tola/ webbe in oculo (f. 142r). The collection contains two recipes that are associated with specific persons: Pillule regis Francie (f. 141r) and Tractatus per A.H. ad menstraua prouocandum (f. 142r).

listBibl.bibl: Mooney (1995), pp. 138-139 [transcriptions of the Middle English recipes]

msItem.title: Collection of medical oils, waters
msItem.incipit: 142r Tisana sic fit
msItem.explicit: 143v iuncturis in nodis articulorum digerit et purgat"

msItem.title: Medical notes
msItem.incipit: 143v Nota quod ydropis suta idem est quod Tympanites
msItem.explicit: 143v Nota quod bona digestio facit bonum colorem quia bonus color est effectus bone digestionis

msItem.title: Poem on the Signs of the Zodiac and the Four Elements
msItem.incipit: 143v Terrea sunt signa taurus uiro capriconrum
msItem.explicit: 143v Igni sunt similes aries leo qui tenet archum

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: The first recipe is titled: Cerebro nocent. Two recipes follow, one for cooling the stomach, and another for sleeping well.

msItem.title: Two medical recipes
msItem.note: The recipes, involving a plaster and ointment, were added by the same 15th century that added astrological tracts to f. 144v.

msItem.title: Tract on 32 unlucky days
msItem.rubric: 144v Quicumque in aliquo dierum subsequencium nascetur non diu viuet . Qui infirmatur non evadet [...] Et tales dies sunt in Anno 32bo:
msItem.incipit: 144v In Januare sunt .7. dies scilicet 1. 2. 4. 5. 10. 15. et 18.
msItem.explicit: 144v In December .3. dies scilicet 6. 7. et 15. quibus caueat ne incipiat aliquid hijs diebus si bene vult terminare
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that has added medical recipes to f. 144r and the other astrological tracts on f. 144v.

msItem.title: Tract on three bad days for bloodletting
msItem.incipit: 144v Item sunt alij .3. dies in quibus nulla cuiuslibet necessitatis occasione licet homini vel pecori sanguinem minuere . vel pocionem accipere
msItem.explicit: 144v Et si quis aucam manducauerit hijs tribus diebus ante .40. diem morietur
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that has added medical recipes to f. 144r and the other astrological tracts on f. 144v.

msItem.title: Lunar prognostics for travelling
msItem.textLang: Latin text with a Middle English rubric
msItem.rubric: 144v Here ȝe may se in what signe it is good . And in wich it is perlous to take ony jorny in
msItem.incipit: 144v Scilicet luna in Ariete mane ne periculum subeas
msItem.explicit: 144v luna in piscibus mane in dampneris viando
msItem.note: Added by the same 15th-century hand that has added medical recipes to f. 144r and the other astrological tracts on f. 144v.
The Middle English rubric is not recorded in Mooney (1995).

msItem.title: Draft sentence
msItem.incipit: 144v Beware off my shape
msItem.note: Full transcription. Added (3x) in the 16th century, copying an inscription in a decorative banderol that accompanies a drawing of a dog in the lower margin of f. 71v.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

note.p: A loose handwritten note by Professor Linne Mooney (dated 22 July 2003) notes that the manuscript is misbound and that the correct order should be: i-iv, 89-120, 1-88, 121-144.

signatures.p: Leaf signatures consisting of combinations of letters from the Roman alphabet and Roman numerals in the lower outer corners of the rectos of the first or both halves of quires: Quires 1-11 (ff. 1-88): e-p; Quires 12-15 (ff. 89-120): a-d; and Quires 18 (ff. 137-144): t.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords written in decorative banderols of dark ink (often accompanied by hybrid, zoomorphic or human figures) in the lower inner corners of the last versos of quires.

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and line ruling. Two columns. 35-37 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: The manuscript has been copied in an anglicana script by the Franciscan friar John Holbeach [Holbeche] (fl. 1411) (see Origin for further details on Holbeach). It is possible, as Winston Black suggests (see the introduction to this catalogue record), that Holbeach added to a pre-existing combined herbal and lapidary on ff. 89-113). However, this is uncertain: the apparent differences between the handwriting in this part and the rest of the manuscript may have arisen from Holbeach's use of a darker ink and a quill with a broader nib, as well as an initial intention to imitate the style of the handwriting and decoration of his exemplar.

Additional texts to the manuscript's opening (ff. [iii] recto-[iv] recto) and final leaves (ff. 144r-144v) and margins throughout are written in a variety of cursive scripts from the 15th- and 16th centuries.

decoNote.p: An original drawing of a dog with a collar and a bell in dark ink in the lower margin of f. 71v. The dog is accompanied by a banderol that cautions the reader: Bewar of my shappe (these words are repeated on f. 144v by a different 15th- or 16th-century hand on f. 144v).

Catchwords written inside decorative banderols in dark ink, almost all accompanied by an animal, hybrid, or human figure in dark or red ink: see 8v (hybrid with a ? flute), 16v (rabbit), 24v (hybrid), 32v (bird), 48v (ape), 56v (hybrid), 64v (a human foot; evidently illustrating the catchwords: habenti pedes),72v (a man with a ? flute), 80v (two feet with stigmas disappearing into a cloud; evidently illustrating the catchwords: Alia die ascendit), 88v (a crowned hybrid with a banderol bidding the reader far wel, 96v (rabbit), 104v (hybrid), 120v (hybrid).
A circular diagram with information for prognostication is drawn in red ink on f. 75v.
A full-page diagram of the Zodiac Man, bearded and crowned, drawn with dark ink and featuring the names of the Signs of the Zodiac on his body in red ink on f. 76r.
A small drawing within the columns of a six-pointed star in dark and red ink that represents a figure that needs to be drawn on a gemstone or worn on another type of amulet on ff. 69r, and f. 69v.
Manicules consisting of hands wearing jewelled gloves in dark or red ink (see ff. 42v, 50r, 54v).

Added 15th- and 16th-century marginal drawings, including: a drawing of a deer in brown ink and a goat in red ink on f. ii verso; a goat in red ink, with the inscription capra in the lower margin of f. 10v. a human figure (effaced) in the outer margin of f. 32r; human heads and figures in ink or plummet on ff. 46r (lower margin, a ? jester), 47v (lower margin), 52v (lower margin) (2x), 55r (lower margin) [detailed drawing of a man in Tudor dress], 86r (outer margin) [2x a woman with head dress] 91v [man with Tudor cap], 96r (upper margin) [woman in headdress], 100r (lower margin), and 128v (outer margin) [perhaps representing John Skeyton]; a man's head with an arrow in his eye in red ink on f. 51r [illustrating a recipe for treating eye injuries]; a dog and a dog's head red ink in the upper margin of f. 67r; a drawing of a human body, copying the Zodiac Man on f. 76r; bird heads (4x) in brown ink in the outer margin of f. 83r; a castle in dark ink (no colours) in the lower margin of f. 97v (perhaps Hampton Court); a cannon in dark ink in the upper margin of f. 98r; a queen, probably Elizabeth I modelled on Elizabethan coins with her portrait, in the lower margins of ff. 98r, 100r, and 101v (2x); a woman with headdress and a pendant in the outer margin of f. 117r; a castle on a hill in dark ink and coloured with green ink inside a square frame in the outer margin of f. 119r.
Ascenders of letters on the top lines of pages are sometimes decorated with drawings of fish in dark ink (see ff. 68v, 72r).

One large (3 lines) puzzle initial in blue and red ink and with a human face drawn with red ink inside the letter on f. 43r; and one large (2 lines) blue initial with the head of a zoomorphic or hybrid figure inside the letter outlines in red ink, inside a frame of red penwork decoration and red pen-flourishing extending into the margins, on f. 89r.

Large (3-4 lines) puzzle initials in blue and red with penwork decoration in red ink at the beginning of new texts or major divisions throughout (but not on ff. 50r-88v and 121r-143v, which do not feature the use of blue ink).

Large (2-3 lines) plain initials in blue or red, sometimes with minor forms of decoration, typically used for minor textual divisions except for sections of the manuscript that only feature initials in red ink (ff. 50r-88v and 121r-143v). These sections also feature large (3 lines) initials in red ink for major text divisions.
Titles for new works are written in red ink.
Line-fillers consist of wavey lines in red ink.
Paraphs in blue or red ink.
Large regular initials in dark ink sometimes higlighted with red ink (see ff. 49v, 51r, 67r).
Small regular initials or words at the start of lines are occasionally highlighted in yellow (see ff. 1r-26v, 89r-120v and ff. 137r-143v).

note.p: Quire numbers in pencil added by a modern hand to the outer lower corners of the first rectos of quires.

binding.p: 18th- or 19th-century half white vellum binding with grey paper sides over pasteboards.

origin.p: The manuscript was copied by the Franciscan friar John Holbeach [Holbeche] (fl. 1411)John Holbeach [Holbeche], fl. 1411, who was active as a scribe at Cambridge and ordained to hear confessions in the diocese of Ely in 1411 (Holbeach seems to have copied the entire manuscript but for another theory see Winston Black's introduction for this catalogue record and the Script section). Holbeach signs his name on f. 66v: scribe Johannes Holbeche [...] ordinis minorum. Holbeach also asked for prayers for his soul in colophons he added while copying Nicholas of Lyra's Postilla litteralis in uetus testamentum, now Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 85 (e.g. see ff. 101v and 235v) [see Robson (2018), p. 43; Jones (2022), p. 220].

provenance.p: John Gylberd (fl. 1450-1550) Gylbert, John, fl. 1450-1550: unidentified owner or user of he manuscript. His name inscribed on f. i verso: John Gylberd.

William Field [Feld or Feeld] (fl. 1500-1600) Field [Feld or Feeld], William, fl. 1500-1600: unidentified owner of the manuscript, apparently a clerk who used the margins for drafting letters and indentures.

His ownership inscriptions on f. 13r: Iste liber pertinet as I drew in my mynde ad me Willelmus ffeld so gentill and kind a pena inferna . god him defend ad vitam eternam at his lives end and Iste liber pertinet as I drew in my mynde ad me willelmus ffelde so gentill and so kinde A pena inferna Jesu him defend Ad vitam eternam At his lives end. Further ownership inscriptions are found in the outer margin of f. 20v (Iste liber pertinet as I drew in my mynd ad me Willelmus ffeld so gentell and so kind a pena Inferna god him deffend ad vitam eternam at his liffes end), the upper margin of f. 44r (Iste liber pertinet as I drew in mynd ad me William ffeld aso gentill and kind a pena inferna), the outer margin of f. 50v (Iste liber pertinet as I drew in mynd ad me W), the outer margin of f. 55r (Iste liber pertinet as I drew in mynd ad me William ffeld so gent[e]ll and so kind a pena Inferna god him defend [the first half of this inscription is then repeated below twice]). His unfinished ownership inscriptions occur on f. 63v (Iste liber pertinent as I drew in my mynd), f. 66r (Iste liber pertinet ?boare [2x]) and f. 120v (Iste liber pertinet [3x]).

Inscriptions of his name can be found throughout the manuscript: Willelmo ffe on f. 20v, William ffeld [2x] on f. 44r (outer margin), William feld per attornatum in the upper margin of f. 46r, William feeld in the outer margin of 47v (upside down), William inscribed (with the name Harison) on f. 55r (lower margin), Wyllyam Fylde (inscribed with the name Lettes Wryght by the same hand) in the upper margin of f. 81r, William ffeld written upside down (2x) in the lower margin of f. 82v, William written (2x) in the upper margin and William ffeld (2x with the name of John Skeyton in the same hand) and William per attornatum suum op. se writen in the lower margin of f. 83r, Per me Willelmum written (2x) in the upper margin of f. 86v, William feelde inscribed two times in different scripts (Italic and Gothic cursive) and William sed written in the upper margin of f. 106v and William feld per attornatum eorum se[u] in the upper margin of f. 125r.

His name below the full title of Queen Elizabeth I in the lower margin of f. 95v: Ad Cur. manerij serenissimi et invictissimi domine Regine Elizabethe dei graciae angliae ffrauncie et hibernie ffidei defens et in terre Ecclesie Anglicane et Hibernie superius caput et fidei per me Willelmus ffeld.

His name also occurs in relation to a possible client or patron on f. 34r (outer margin): Per me Willelmus ffeld seruient. Edwardis [or Edmundis] Wryghte [...]. The same inscription occurs in the upper margin of f. 101v.

John Skeyton (fl. 1500-1600) Sketyon, John, fl. 1500-1600: unidentified owner or user of the manuscript, probably a relation of William Field (see f. 83r). His name can be found throughout the manuscript: John Skeyton is my name dwelling at the [...] written in the lower margin of f. 43v, John Skeyton is may na written in the lower margin of f. 49v, John Skeyton (with the name William Felde in the same hand) in the lower margin of f. 83r, and John Skeyton in the outer margin of f. 128v. His first name occurs in various inscriptions: John on 17v (lower margin), John servaunt vnto the written three times in different colours (red, green, and brown ink) in the lower margin (upside down) of f. 78r. That I may Johannem written in the outer margin of f. 106v. His memorandum in the outer margin of f. 45v: Memorandum that I John - John Servaunt vnto the Right worshippfull Sir John. His name inscribed with reference to a client or patron in the outer margin of f. 34r: Per me Johannem Skeyton seruient. Georgis Harison Generosis and Quod [...] per me Johannem. (a George Haryson and John Skeyton are grantors in a indenture concerning the manor of Pocklington dated 1562-1563, see TNA E 326/12875).

Ferdinand Pope (fl. 1500-1600) Pope, Ferdinand, fl. 1500-1600: unidentified possible owner or user of the manuscript: his full name inscribed in the outer margin of f. 50v: fferdinand pope the xxth day [...]. His first name fferdinand inscribed on ff. 1r, 13r, 51v (2x), and 53r (2x). However, despite suggestions that Ferdinand Pope inscribed his name into the manuscript it is possible that these inscriptions were in fact all added by William Field (see his provenance entry above). The latter used the manuscript's margins for drafting letters and indentures and was clearly able to execute different types of scripts.

Robert Stringer (fl. 1500-1600) Stringer, Robert, fl. 1500-1600: unidentified possible owner or user of this manuscript. His name inscribed in a draft sentence in the outer margin of f. 33v: That I may serve thee to the honor and glorie amen by me yours to commaunde Robert stringer. However, despite the suggestion that Robert Stringer inscribed his name into the manuscript it is possible that these inscriptions were in fact all added by William Field (see his provenance entry above). The latter used the manuscript's margins for drafting letters and indentures and was clearly able to execute different types of scripts.

Edmund York (fl. 1500-1600) York, Edmund, fl. 1500-1600: unidentified possible owner or user of the manuscript: his name inscribed twice in calligraphic letters in the outer margin of f. 39v: emunde yorke and Edmounde york. His name is written five times in different scripts into the margin of f. 47v. His first name Edmund and Edmunde is also inscribed in the outer margin of f. 44r and the upper margin of f. 106v. However, despite suggestions that Edmund York may have inscribed his name into the manuscript it is possible that these inscriptions were in fact all added by William Field (see his provenance entry above). The latter used the manuscript's margins for drafting letters and indentures and was clearly able to execute different types of scripts.

Thomas Harison (fl. 1500-1600) Harison, Thomas, fl. 1500-1600: unidentified possible owner or user of this manuscript. A name inscription seemingly referring to the scribe occurs on f. 55r (outer margin): Per me Thomam / Thomam. Similarly, he appears to refer to himself on f. 71r (outer margin): Indentor mei per me Thomam (but note that this inscription is immediately preceded by a reference to William Field in a similar if not the same hand: Ad me W). His name is also inscribed in a draft sentence in the upper margin of f. 34r: Thomaus Harizon and then chall. His first name (Thomam) is inscribed in the outer margins of ff. 96v and 126r. The name Harison is thrice inscribed in the outer margin of f. 65v (together with the inscription vic. com. Sallopiae). However, despite suggestions that Thomas Harison inscribed his name into the manuscript it is possible that these inscriptions were in fact all added by William Field (see his provenance entry above). The latter used the manuscript's margins for drafting letters and indentures and was clearly able to execute different types of scripts.

Thomas Faten de la Rosse (fl. 1560/1) Harison, Thomas, fl. 1560/1: unidentified possible owner or user of this manuscript. His name is inscribed in the outer margin of f. 73r: Thomas Faten De La Rosse [...] Anno tercio Regine Elizabeth. His surname de la Rosse also occurs in a draft indenture in red ink in the outer margin of f. 67r. However, despite suggestions that Thomas Faten inscribed his name into the manuscript it is possible that these inscriptions were in fact all added by William Field (see his provenance entry above). The latter used the manuscript's margins for drafting letters and indentures and was clearly able to execute different types of scripts.

Lettes [Lettis] Wright, fl. 1500-1600 Wright, Lettes [Lettis, fl. 150001600: unidentified possible owner or user of this manuscript. Her name Lettes Wryght is inscribed in red ink (together with the name Wyllyam Fylde) in the upper margin of f. 81r and by itself in the outer margin of f. 128r. Her name also appears an inscription in red ink in the upper margin of f. 75r: Lettis wright do forge[...] aquayntaunce). However, despite the suggestions that Lettes Wright inscribed his name into the manuscript it is possible that these inscriptions were in fact all added by William Field (see his provenance entry above). The latter used the manuscript's margins for drafting letters and indentures and was clearly able to execute different types of scripts.

Jane Wright, fl. 1500-1600 Wright, Jane, fl. 150001600: unidentified possible owner or user of this manuscript. Her name is twice inscribed in red ink in the outer margin of f. 126r: Jane Wright. However, despite the suggestion that Jane Wright inscribed his name into the manuscript it is possible that these inscriptions were in fact all added by William Field (see his provenance entry above). The latter used the manuscript's margins for drafting letters and indentures and was clearly able to execute different types of scripts.

Jone Pynson, fl. 1500-1600 Pynson, Jone, fl. 150001600: unidentified possible owner or user of this manuscript. (?) Her name is inscribed in red ink in the outer margin of f. 126r: Jone pynson. However, despite the suggestion that Jone Pynson inscribed his name into the manuscript it is possible that these inscriptions were in fact all added by William Field (see his provenance entry above). The latter used the manuscript's margins for drafting letters and indentures and was clearly able to execute different types of scripts.

One of the manuscripts of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635/6-1702, dean of York, antiquary and fellow of Trinity College Cambridge. The manuscript is listed as no. 363 (see f. i verso) in the list of Gale's manuscripts in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697).
One of the manuscripts of Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, antiquary and scholar, son of Thomas Gale. Inherited from his father.

acquisition.p: Donated to Trinity College by Roger Gale (1672-1744)Gale, Roger, 1672-1744, son of Thomas Gale (1635/6-1702), in 1738. The alpha-numerical elements of its current classmark are printed on three (much worn) labels pasted onto the spine (O, 9, 10), and those of its current and previous classmarks are inscribed in the manuscript: O.9.10 in brown ink on the inside of the front cover ; I.20 and O.16.16 [both crossed] and O.9.10 in dark ink on f. i verso; O.16.16 [crossed out] in dark ink on f. iii recto. Its printed ex libris with coat of arms and name Collegium S.S. et Individuae Trinitatis in Academia Cantabrigensis pasted in the outer margin of f. iii recto.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College, Cambridge: a descriptive catalogue, 3 (1902); and Linne R. Mooney, Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XI (Woodbridge: Brewer, 1995).

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.
